text: There was EV backing Harris at 2.5. The margin of victory is within error bars for polling, if you factored that in, the smart bet was to back Harris or lay Trump. Just because somebody was right in picking a winning bet, it doesn’t mean they got value. Keep doing that over and over again and eventually you’ll get ruined.

text: I think the most optimistic probabilistic prediction I saw would have priced Trump at about 1.96 when he was trading in the 1.75 region. The fact that people who don’t understand EV picked a winner does not negate that they don’t understand EV. I traded out over the weekend when Harris price fell a little, so I’m flat on the market (I hedged to zero believing she had momentum but didn’t want to be in the market any market), but still think I’m ahead of idiots picking winners no matter the price.

text: I'm pretty glad it's over to be honest. I layed Trump then backout out of it the day after for a nice profit of 85 pence (after commission). It mystifies me why political markets gain so much attention from the betting community. World Cup has the same frequency and doesn't seem to generate anywhere near as much discussion. In terms of things unrelated to betting, the most disconcerting thing about Western democracies is the shockingly low calibre of people that we have to choose between (although that's of course just personal sentiment).

text: <@U027P3N2WMQ> I have to work for a living, no ghosting intended. I don’t think I was wrong: it was EV with the info had to hand. In fact, I’m not sure that Fredi + MAGA pickers ever had enough data to suggest they were betting at +EV prices. To answer that is going to need a deeper understanding on whether polling was structurally wrong (wrong samples), if people were actively lying (so how do you find true data?), or if people changed their minds close to election time, meaning it was +EV until the counts came in.

text:
As to wider ramifications, if I did fiscals I’d now start to think about:

• Short US interest rates and the dollar - they’re gonna need to drop interest rates in the next few years to counter the tariff hit, and I think Euro will take a stronger roll as a reserve currency in next couple of years as the 2025 project picks up steam
• Go long oil - ME war will now escalate under US diplomatic cover of “not our problem, you lot figure it out”, which likely leads to Israel, Iran and Saudi all side eyeing each other with nukes by 2030
• Short anything touching Eastern Europe - or “Russia” as it’ll be known in 5 years
• Go long anything that helps EU biz/public sector get away from US tech - they’ve been paranoid for years, it’ll now accelerate, fast.
I’ve seen a lot of bad take reactions to a lot of elections, and mine might be one in itself, but I don’t see a realistic scenario as to how this doesn’t end up in a US economy fucked by import tariffs, genocide in Gaza & West Bank spilling into Lebanon (and dragging Iran and Saudi in), and Russia pushing a mountain of North Korean bullet fodder towards Kyiv and Warsaw…

text: <@U80AMMRKP> that isn’t how EV works. You don’t grade getting 10/1 on a pot when you have 2 kings before the flop based on the fact your opponent got his 6/2 inside flush hit on the river… he made -EV, you made +EV. You keep making those same calls over and over again, you win, he loses. If you’re trying to pick winners and then assessing how well you pick winners and ignoring the price you’re taking that and if it makes sense, well, good luck to you, but backing Harris at 2.7 with the info known at the time was superb EV, regardless of how the bet settled

text: I thought it was a coin toss. 2.5-2.7 about a coin toss is +EV. Turns out true price was 1.01 but we only know that after the horse had jumped the last fence 10 lengths clear - how do we assess the EV when they’re still walking around the paddock? I’m stretching the metaphor, but even when I go racing for fun I’m not trying to find a winner, I’m trying to figure out if there is value. If you think that is me just pretending to find a way to be right all the time, fair enough

text: <@U80AMMRKP> 1.9ish - polling put him slightly ahead. We did not have data to support shy Trump voter, sampling error, whatever else is uncovered as influencing in weeks and months to come. You can only make the call with the info you have. It’s the problem with this sort of betting, you deal with incomplete information, you are managing variance in an unknown distribution, this isn’t dice, roulette or even poker where you can do the maths with absolute or high degrees of confidence. It’s judgement you can add to with more information. I’d ask where is the additional info that made sense to price in that polymarket did price in? I’m not sure it exists. I’m not certain, but in my judgement, with the information available last week, Harris backers had EV, Trump backers didn’t…

text:
Bottom line (thinking of lurkers when I post this): For what we do; this just isn't how you do it, the whole thing. You don't pick single events and agonise over them before and after, you take loads of events, look at them all together and assign EVs to groups of bets, not individual bets.

Betting at +EV on small numbers of events is a thing, but for the most part it's not what we do for a living, this shit is just for a laugh.

elements.text:
Bottom line (thinking of lurkers when I post this): For what we do; this just isn't how you do it, the whole thing. You don't pick single events and agonise over them before and after, you take loads of events, look at them all together and assign EVs to groups of bets, not individual bets.

Betting at +EV on small numbers of events is a thing, but for the most part it's not what we do for a living, this shit is just for a laugh.

text: I'd argue that the EV comes from the fact there were hundreds of polls that had been analysed, weighted and shifted based on multiple orgs approaches - including, most famously, 538's analysis  - that showed a coin toss was a reasonable summation of all the public source information to hand. It wasn't a single poll and a single market and everyone just going "the poll is wrong", it was tens of millions of dollars worth of data analysis that produced an indication and a model. It's a single market event, but not a single data point.

elements.text: I'd argue that the EV comes from the fact there were hundreds of polls that had been analysed, weighted and shifted based on multiple orgs approaches - including, most famously, 538's analysis  - that showed a coin toss was a reasonable summation of all the public source information to hand. It wasn't a single poll and a single market and everyone just going "the poll is wrong", it was tens of millions of dollars worth of data analysis that produced an indication and a model. It's a single market event, but not a single data point.

text: To the people saying Nate Silver is clearly wrong, this outcome (Trump winning all seven swing states) was literally the most likely outcome of his model for the past month. His final forecast had either candidate with a 50% chance of winning, which isn’t the same as expecting them to both get exactly 50% of the vote.

elements.text: To the people saying Nate Silver is clearly wrong, this outcome (Trump winning all seven swing states) was literally the most likely outcome of his model for the past month. His final forecast had either candidate with a 50% chance of winning, which isn’t the same as expecting them to both get exactly 50% of the vote.

text: He did have some election night model thing going last night which was admittedly shit, but I assume everyone is talking about his pre-election forecasting.

elements.text: He did have some election night model thing going last night which was admittedly shit, but I assume everyone is talking about his pre-election forecasting.
